questions.question: What is the first crucial step in the data collection and preparation process?

options.A: Data Cleaning
options.B: Data Integration
options.C: Defining the data requirements and sources
options.D: Data Transformation

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary source of data?

options.A: Government statistical reports
options.B: Academic research papers
options.C: Customer surveys conducted by your company
options.D: Online news articles

questions.question: What is the difference between primary and secondary data?

options.A: Primary data is numerical, while secondary data is categorical.
options.B: Primary data is collected firsthand, while secondary data is data that has already been collected by someone else.
options.C: Primary data is always more reliable than secondary data.
options.D: There is no significant difference between them.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a secondary data source?

options.A: A focus group interview.
options.B: Sensor data collected from a machine.
options.C: A publicly available dataset on Kaggle.
options.D: Direct observations of customer behavior.

questions.question: What is data wrangling?

options.A: The process of building machine learning models.
options.B: The visual representation of data.
options.C: The process of cleaning, structuring, and enriching raw data into a more suitable format for analysis.
options.D: The storage and management of large databases.

questions.question: Why is data cleaning an essential step in data preparation?

options.A: To make the data visually appealing.
options.B: To reduce the size of the dataset.
options.C: To handle missing values, outliers, and inconsistencies that can negatively impact analysis.
options.D: To speed up the data collection process.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common technique for handling missing numerical data?

options.A: Deleting the entire dataset.
options.B: Ignoring the missing values.
options.C: Imputation using the mean, median, or mode.
options.D: Converting the numerical data to categorical.

questions.question: What is an outlier in a dataset?

options.A: A data point that appears most frequently.
options.B: A data point that is consistent with the majority of the data.
options.C: A data point that significantly deviates from other observations.
options.D: A data point that is missing.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common method for detecting outliers in numerical data?

options.A: Calculating the average.
options.B: Using scatter plots and box plots.
options.C: Counting the number of data points.
options.D: Sorting the data alphabetically.

questions.question: What is data transformation?

options.A: The process of collecting data from various sources.
options.B: The process of cleaning and handling missing values.
options.C: The process of converting data from one format or structure to another to make it suitable for analysis.
options.D: The process of visualizing data insights.

questions.question: Which of the following is a data transformation technique?

options.A: Data deletion.
options.B: Data imputation.
options.C: Normalization or scaling.
options.D: Outlier detection.

questions.question: What is the purpose of data integration?

options.A: To reduce the size of the data.
options.B: To combine data from multiple sources into a unified dataset.
options.C: To remove all inconsistencies from the data.
options.D: To visualize data in different formats.

questions.question: What challenges might arise during data integration?

options.A: Different data formats and schemas.
options.B: Inconsistent naming conventions.
options.C: Duplicate records across sources.
options.D: All of the above.

questions.question: What is feature engineering?

options.A: The process of selecting the most relevant data sources.
options.B: The process of cleaning and handling missing values in features.
options.C: The process of creating new features from existing ones to improve model performance.
options.D: The process of deploying machine learning models.

questions.question: Why is data quality important in data science?

options.A: High-quality data always leads to simple models.
options.B: Garbage in, garbage out; the quality of the data directly impacts the reliability of the analysis and models.
options.C: Low-quality data is easier to process.
options.D: Data quality is only important for visualization.

questions.question: What are some common data collection methods?

options.A: Surveys, experiments, and observations.
options.B: Data cleaning and transformation.
options.C: Model building and evaluation.
options.D: Data visualization and reporting.

questions.question: What is the potential impact of biased data collection?

options.A: It always leads to more accurate models.
options.B: It can result in unfair or inaccurate conclusions and predictions.
options.C: It simplifies the data analysis process.
options.D: It has no significant impact on the final results.

questions.question: What considerations should be taken into account when collecting sensitive data?

options.A: Only the volume of data matters.
options.B: Ethical guidelines, privacy regulations, and informed consent.
options.C: The speed at which data can be collected.
options.D: The ease of storing the data.

questions.question: What is the role of data governance in data collection and preparation?

options.A: To build machine learning models.
options.B: To ensure the security of the data.
options.C: To establish policies and procedures for managing data throughout its lifecycle, including collection and preparation.
options.D: To visualize the final results of the analysis.

questions.question: Which of the following tools or technologies is commonly used for data collection and preparation?

options.A: Matplotlib
options.B: Scikit-learn
options.C: Pandas
options.D: TensorFlow
